awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:   Remote monitoring and assessment tool for spinal care patients
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a system to measure musculoskeletal function and monitor patient movements throughout the day. Lower back pain is the leading cause of global disability and up to 80% of Americans will experience lower back pain in their life. The diagnosis and treatment pathways for these patients are complex, expensive (ranging between $10,815 to $87,000 for non-surgical and surgical interventions), and often ambiguous. For the 1.62 million Americans who undergo fusion procedures each year, their treatment is plagued with complication rates as high as 50% and revision rates upwards of 36%. Despite this, rates of these procedures are growing. Between 1998 and 2008, cervical, thoracic, and lumbar fusions rose by 90%, 61%, and 141%. Recent studies have found that up to 17% of spine fusions performed were on patients who should not have been recommended surgeries. The proposed technology may allow for longitudinal tracking and functional quantitative assessment of musculoskeletal disorders and provide personalized care and decreased complications.  In addition, the proposed technology may be applied to pain management, the orthopedic extremity market, and sports training.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a remote monitoring and assessment tool to provide dynamic metrics and guide personalized treatment for spine care patients. The proposed technology uses a three-part system that consists of a wearable array, a motion analysis and calibration algorithm that models the spine in 3D, and a clinical report that translates recorded data into clinical metrics.  The goal is to analyze dynamic movement, muscular compensation, and pain over a 48-hour window, providing spine surgeons and pain management practitioners with objective measurements of their patients outside of the clinic.  The technology builds on recent studies that show that the average spinal curvature may drastically differ from standing radiographic images, which can lead to significant errors in surgical planning when not considered. The proposed sensing array will be placed on the patient in a controlled environment at the end of a standard consultation.  Developed sensor calibration methods will be used to increase accuracy and reduces placement error, providing a predictive pose estimation system. Advancements in this field may enable previously uncaptured functional assessments of patients in a natural environment and lead to substantial improvements in remote monitoring.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our team participated in the NSF I-Corps program with the goal of revolutionizing spinal assessment and treatment planning. Through over 200+ interviews with doctors, patients, hospital administrators, sales representatives, and other stakeholders, we worked to understand the challenges and needs within the field of spinal health. Our overarching goal was to aid in the assessment and treatment of individuals suffering from spinal conditions and back pain, a process that can often take patients over six months to find an effective solution. Through this time patients suffer and are left with tremendous uncertainty in their care. Patients often undergo treatments that do not improve their pain, leading to over $200,000 in costs to the healthcare system. Initially, we believed the market needed a wearable device to provide physicians with insights into patients’ at-home habits and spinal function. The I-Corps program helped us refine this hypothesis and better understand our customer needs and the value proposition of our system.

Throughout the program, our team validated significant interest from academic medical centers and identified a strong market in private medical practices. The private sector offered a novel market we had not previously explored, demonstrating an additional need to enhance clinic efficiency and save time in the assessment process, distinct from the academic surgeon’s interest in adding to ongoing studies and gaining more valuable data from existing protocols. One of the standout moments during the I-Corps program was when talking with doctors about a possible software solution to a problem that they were having. This was a small part of our existing system and was not intended to be a major feature. However, one doctor after learning about the function said, "Give this to me now! I want to use this on every one of my patients." This strong endorsement highlighted a secondary product opportunity within the existing software, which we have since expanded upon, accelerating the path to market and revenue generation.

The I-Corps program has been transformative, providing the team with the confidence to establish CurveAssure, a company focused on commercializing this technology. Our goal is to equip doctors with tools that enable more efficient and accurate patient assessments, thereby improving treatment outcomes for individuals with spinal conditions. With over 200 interviews conducted, our team is also incredibly excited about additional customer segments beyond the spine space, including physical therapy, orthopedics, and pain management specialists. The invaluable I-Corps program has fueled our enthusiasm and empowered us to continue customer discovery in order to grow CurveAssure by providing value to our customers.


Last Modified: 06/20/2024
Modified by: Youseph Yazdi
